revision.text:
{{Year box}} '''1835 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * Still trying to resolve the English Championship title issue, [[James Burke (boxer)|James Burke]] has two scheduled fights but neither can take place. First, Harry Preston refuses to fight him; and then Young Langan is arrested on the eve of his fight for assaulting a police officer.<ref name="JB">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/burke-j.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – James Burke]. Retrieved on 7 November 2009.</ref> * 21 July — in a non-title bout between two future contenders, [[Ben Caunt]] is disqualified for an alleged foul, striking [[William Thompson (boxer)|William "Bendigo" Thompson]] when Thompson is sitting in his corner.<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/thompson.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Bendigo]. Retrieved on 7 November 2009.</ref>
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * Powerless to prevent the use of [[roundarm|roundarm bowling]], MCC finally amends the [[Laws of Cricket]] to make it legal. The relevant part of the Laws states: :: ''if the hand be above the shoulder in the delivery, the umpire must call "No Ball"''. * Bowlers’ hands now go above the shoulder and the 1835 Law must be reinforced in 1845 by removing benefit of the doubt from the bowler in the matter of his hand's height when delivering the ball. * The Laws are also changed to enforce a compulsory follow on if a team is 100 runs behind on first innings. '''England''' * Most runs – [[James Cobbett]] 156 @ 15.60 (HS 31*) * Most wickets – [[William Lillywhite]] 42 (BB 7–?)
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Preserve (horse)|Preserve]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Ibrahim * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Mündig]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – [[Queen of Trumps]] * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Queen of Trumps]]
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * The [[Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]] is not held this year
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year to 1850}}
[[Category:Sports by year]] [[Category:1835 in sports| ]]

{{Year box}} '''1888 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[American football]]== '''College championship''' * [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|College football national championship]] – [[Yale Bulldogs football|Yale Bulldogs]] (coached by [[Walter Camp]]) '''Events''' * Tackling below the waist is legalised.
==[[Association football]]== '''England''' * [[FA Cup final]] – [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] 2–1 [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]] at [[The Oval]] * Walsall Town and Walsall Swifts merge to form [[Walsall F.C.|Walsall Football Club]]. The club initially plays under the name of Walsall Town Swifts. * Small Heath, later [[Birmingham City]], is the first football club to form a limited company * 7 April — [[Tinsley Lindley]] scores in his ninth consecutive [[England national football team|England]] game, a [[England national football team records|record]] that still stands. '''Origin of the Football League''' * One of the problems facing [[professionalism]] is the lack of competitive matches, especially for teams that have been knocked out of the [[FA Cup]]. It is self–evident that crowds for friendly fixtures are much lower, which means a reduction in revenue and consequent struggle to pay wages. * [[Aston Villa]]'s Scottish director [[William McGregor (football)|William McGregor]] seeks a solution by asking other professional clubs to arrange annual home and away fixtures on a competitive basis, with points to be awarded for winning and drawing. Following a conference between club directors on 23 March, the English [[Football League]] is founded on 17 April as one division of twelve clubs. * The founder members are: [[Accrington F.C.]] (1888–1893), [[Aston Villa]], [[Blackburn Rovers]], [[Bolton Wanderers]], [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]], [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]], [[Everton F.C.|Everton]], [[Notts County]], [[Preston North End]], [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke F.C.]], [[West Bromwich Albion]] and [[Wolverhampton Wanderers]]. '''India''' * [[Durand Cup]] instituted by [[Mortimer Durand]] as recreation for British troops stationed in India. It is the oldest tournament in India and the third oldest in the world. '''Scotland''' * [[Scottish Cup final]] – [[Renton F.C.|Renton]] 6–1 [[Cambuslang F.C.|Cambuslang]] * [[Celtic Football Club]] is founded by members of the Marist Order, a teaching institute, as a way of raising money for a poor children's charity. The club's first ground is a piece of rented land not far from the present [[Celtic Park]]. Celtic's first recorded match is a home "friendly" against [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]]; Celtic win 5–2 in what is therefore the inaugural "[[Old Firm|Old Firm Game]]".
==[[Baseball]]== '''National championship''' * [[National League]] v. [[American Association (19th century)|American Association]] – [[New York Giants (NL)|New York Giants]] (NL) defeats [[Saint Louis Cardinals]] (AA) 6 games to 4. '''Events''' * The last of many adjustments finally sets four balls and three strikes for a "walk" and a strikeout.
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * The inaugural [[World Welterweight Champion]] is [[Paddy Duffy]] of Boston, Massachusetts who is recognised following his 17th round knockout of [[Billy McMillan (boxer)|Billy McMillan]] at Fort Foote, Virginia on 30 October.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cyber Boxing Zone – Lineal Welterweight Champions |url=http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/welter.htm |work= |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hYqUZkyn?url=http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/welter.htm |archivedate=2009-06-15 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-06-13 |df= }}</ref> Duffy retains the title until his death (by tuberculosis) in 1890. The [[welterweight]] division is for fighters weighing between 140 and 147lb. '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>{{cite web|title=Cyber Boxing Zone |url=http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm |work= |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hg1si20f?url=http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm |archivedate=2009-06-20 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-06-17 |df= }}</ref> * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[John L. Sullivan]] * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – [[Jack Nonpareil Dempsey]] * [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship – [[Paddy Duffy]] * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – [[Jack McAuliffe (boxer)|Jack McAuliffe]]
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * After a run of disastrous results over a number of seasons, [[Derbyshire County Cricket Club|Derbyshire]] is demoted from first-class status and the 1888 championship is contested by only eight teams: Gloucestershire, Kent, Lancashire, Middlesex, Nottinghamshire, Surrey, Sussex and Yorkshire. Derbyshire will recover first-class status in 1894 and join the official County Championship in 1895. * 5 July — formation of [[Glamorgan County Cricket Club]] at a meeting in the [[Angel Hotel, Cardiff]]. * Thanks mainly to the bowling of [[Bobby Peel]], [[England national cricket team|England]] defeats [[Australia national cricket team|Australia]] 2–1 to retain [[The Ashes]]. '''England''' * [[Champion County]]<ref>A semi-official seasonal title proclaimed by media consensus prior to December 1889 when the official County Championship is constituted.</ref> – [[Surrey County Cricket Club|Surrey]] * Most runs – [[W. G. Grace]] 1,886 @ 32.51 (HS 215) * Most wickets – [[Charles Turner (Australian cricketer)|Charlie Turner]] 283 @ 11.68 (BB 9–15) * [[Wisden Cricketers of the Year|Wisden Six Great Bowlers of the Year]] – [[George Lohmann]], [[Johnny Briggs (cricketer)|Johnny Briggs]], [[John Ferris (cricketer)|John Ferris]], [[Charles Turner (Australian cricketer)|Charlie Turner]], [[Sammy Woods]], [[Bobby Peel]] '''Australia''' * Most runs – [[Harry Moses]] 815 @ 62.69 (HS 297*) * Most wickets – [[Charles Turner (Australian cricketer)|Charlie Turner]] 106 @ 13.59 (BB 8–39)
==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[1888 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Jack Burns (golfer)|Jack Burns]] '''Other tournaments''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – [[John Ball (golfer)|John Ball]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1888 Grand National|Grand National]] – Playfair * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Briar-root * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Ayrshire (horse)|Ayrshire]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – Ayrshire * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – [[Seabreeze (horse)|Seabreeze]] * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – Seabreeze '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – Mentor '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Harry Cooper '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – The Maroon * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – Theodolite '''USA''' * [[1888 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – MacBeth II * [[Preakness Stakes]] – Refund * [[Belmont Stakes]] – Sir Dixon * [[The Futurity]] – Proctor Knott
==[[Ice hockey]]== * March 15 – [[Montreal Hockey Club]] defeats [[Montreal Victorias]] 2–1 in a playoff to capture the [[1888 AHAC season|1888 AHAC championship]].
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 24 March — [[Cambridge University Boat Club|Cambridge]] wins the 45th [[The Boat Race 1888|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]]
==[[Rugby football]]== '''Home Nations Championship''' * The [[1888 Home Nations Championship]] is the 6th series of the [[Six Nations Championship|Home Nations Championship]] contested by [[Ireland national rugby union team|Ireland]], [[Scotland national rugby union team|Scotland]] and [[Wales national rugby union team|Wales]]. England is excluded due to its refusal to join the [[International Rugby Board]]. The teams win one match apiece and the title is shared by all three. '''Other events''' * The [[1888 British Lions tour to New Zealand and Australia|1888 British Isles tour of New Zealand and Australia]] sees the first overseas touring rugby team from Britain. The tour is a private venture and not authorised by the Home Nations. * The [[1888–1889 New Zealand Native football team]] are the first overseas rugby tourists from the Southern Hemisphere. The team plays matches under [[Rugby union|Rugby football]], [[Australian rules football|Victorian Rules football]] and [[Football (soccer)|Association football]] codes. * [[Bristol Bears|Bristol Football Club]] is formed when the Carlton club merges with rival club Redland Park to create a united Bristol team.
==[[Tennis]]== '''England''' * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Ernest Renshaw]] (GB) defeats [[Herbert Lawford]] (GB) 6–3 7–5 6–0 * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Lottie Dod]] (GB) defeats [[Blanche Bingley Hillyard]] (GB) 6–3 6–3 '''USA''' * [[US Open (tennis)|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Henry Slocum (tennis)|Henry Slocum]] (USA) defeats [[Howard A. Taylor]] (USA) 6–4 6–1 6–0 * [[US Open (tennis)|American Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Bertha Townsend]] (USA) defeats [[Ellen Hansell]] (USA) 6–3 6–5
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year 1851 – 1900}}
[[Category:Sports by year]] [[Category:1888 in sports| ]]

{{Year box}} '''1894 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[American football]]== '''College championship''' * [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|College football national championship]] – [[Yale Bulldogs]]
'''Professional championships''' * [[Western Pennsylvania Professional Football Circuit|Western Pennsylvania champions]] – [[Allegheny Athletic Association]]
'''Events''' * The 1894 [[Harvard–Yale football rivalry|Harvard–Yale]] game, known as the "Hampden Park Blood Bath", results in crippling injuries for four players; the contest is suspended until 1897. The annual [[Army–Navy Game]] is suspended from 1894 till 1898 for similar reasons. One of the major problems is the popularity of mass formations like the [[flying wedge]], in which a large number of offensive players charge as a unit against a similarly arranged defense. The resultant collisions often lead to serious injury and sometimes even death.
==[[Association football]]== '''Austria''' * Foundation of [[First Vienna FC]], which is the oldest club in Austria (22 August). '''England''' * [[The Football League]] – [[Aston Villa]] 44 points, [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] 38, [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] 36, [[Blackburn Rovers]] 34, [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] 34, [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] 33 * [[1894 FA Cup Final|FA Cup final]] – [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]] 4–1 [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] at [[Goodison Park]] * The Football League expands the Second Division from 15 to 16 clubs ahead of the 1894–95 season. [[Darwen F.C.|Darwen]] and Newton Heath ([[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]]) are relegated from the First Division while [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] and Small Heath ([[Birmingham City]]) are promoted. [[Middlesbrough Ironopolis]] and [[Northwich Victoria]] are expelled from the league and three new clubs are elected: [[Bury F.C.|Bury]], [[Burton Wanderers]] (league membership 1894–97) and Leicester Fosse ([[Leicester City]]). * The [[Southern Football League|Southern League]] is founded prior to the 1894–95 season. Some of its early members will eventually join the Football League. '''Scotland''' * [[Scottish Football League]] – [[Glasgow Celtic|Celtic]] * [[1894 Scottish Cup Final|Scottish Cup]] – [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] 3–1 [[Glasgow Celtic|Celtic]] at [[Cathkin Park|Hampden Park]]
==[[Baseball]]== '''National championship''' * [[Baltimore Orioles (19th century)|Baltimore Orioles]] win the first of three successive [[National League]] championships '''Events''' * The [[Temple Cup]] is introduced, lasting until 1897, and matches the National League winner and runner-up in a best–of–seven, post–season championship series. It is also known as the "World's Championship Series" but it fails to gain fan support, partly because three of the four series held will be won by the league runner-up. In 1894, runner-up [[New York Giants (NL)|New York Giants]] defeats champion [[Baltimore Orioles (19th century)|Baltimore Orioles]] 4 games to 0. * 1894 is [[Major League Baseball]]'s highest scoring season as [[Boston Beaneaters]] set the current record for the most runs scored in a season (1220) and another standing record with seven players scoring 100 or more runs; in addition, [[Philadelphia Phillies]] bat .349 for the season with all four outfielders above .400, but finish fourth despite the feat
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * 26 July — [[Tommy Ryan]] defeats [["Mysterious" Billy Smith]] after 20 rounds at [[Minneapolis]] to win the [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship. Ryan will hold the title until 1898, when he vacates it to challenge for the world middleweight title * The inaugural [[World Bantamweight Champion]] is [[Jimmy Barry]] of Chicago who is recognised following his 28th round knockout of [[Casper Leon]] at Lemont, Illinois on 15 September. Barry retains the title until 1899 when he retires undefeated in the whole of his career.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cyber Boxing Zone |url=http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/bantam.htm |work= |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hYdW70CO?url=http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/bantam.htm |archivedate=2009-06-15 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-06-13 |df= }}</ref> The [[bantamweight]] division is for fighters weighing between 112 and 118 lb. '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>{{cite web|title=Cyber Boxing Zone |url=http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm |work= |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hg1si20f?url=http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm |archivedate=2009-06-20 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-06-20 |df= }}</ref> * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[James J. Corbett]] * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – [[Bob Fitzsimmons]] * [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship – [["Mysterious" Billy Smith]] → [[Tommy Ryan]] * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – title vacant * [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship – [[George Dixon (boxer)|George Dixon]] * [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship – [[Jimmy Barry]]
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * The inaugural [[South Africa national cricket team|South African]] tour of England takes place but none of its 24 matches are currently regarded as [[first-class cricket|first-class]] fixtures. '''England''' * [[County Championship]] – [[Surrey CCC|Surrey]] * Most runs – [[Bill Brockwell]] 1491 @ 38.23 (HS 128) * Most wickets – [[Arthur Mold]] 207 @ 12.30 (BB 8–67) * [[Wisden Cricketers of the Year|Wisden Five Young Batsmen of the Season]] – [[Bill Brockwell]], [[Jack Brown (cricketer)|Jack Brown]], [[C B Fry]], [[Tom Hayward]], [[Archie MacLaren]] '''Australia''' * [[Sheffield Shield]] – [[South Australia cricket team|South Australia]] * Most runs – [[George Giffen]] 526 @ 75.14 (HS 205) * Most wickets – [[Charles Turner (Australian cricketer)|Charlie Turner]] 30 @ 12.30 (BB 6–51) '''India''' * [[Bombay Quadrangular|Bombay Presidency]] – [[Europeans cricket team|Europeans]] '''South Africa''' * [[SuperSport Series|Currie Cup]] – [[Natal cricket team|Natal]] '''West Indies''' * [[Inter-Colonial Tournament]] – not contested
==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[1894 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[John Henry Taylor]] '''Other tournaments''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – [[John Ball (golfer)|John Ball]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1894 Grand National|Grand National]] – Why Not * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Amiable]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Ladas (horse)|Ladas]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – Ladas * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – Amiable * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Throstle (horse)|Throstle]] '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – Patron '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Joe Miller '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – The Admiral * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – Blairfinde '''USA''' * [[1894 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – Chant * [[Preakness Stakes]] – Assignee * [[Belmont Stakes]] – Henry of Navarre
==[[Ice hockey]]== '''Events''' * 25 February — [[Ontario Hockey Association]] (OHA) champion [[Ottawa Hockey Club]] resigns from the association, ending Ottawa participation in OHA titles and tournaments. * 22 March 22 — In a playoff to decide the [[1894 AHAC season]] title and the [[Stanley Cup]], [[Montreal Hockey Club]] defeats Ottawa Hockey Club 3–1. * March — Toronto Osgoode Hall defeats [[Queen's Golden Gaels|Queen's University]] of Kingston 3–2 to win the OHA championship.
==[[Motor racing]]== '''Origin''' * 22 July — the world's first competitive motor race was the [[Paris–Rouen (motor race)|Paris to Rouen]]. Although there have previously been some private events, this first real contest is organised by Paris magazine ''[[Le Petit Journal (newspaper)|Le Petit Journal]]''. [[Albert de Dion]] is first to arrive at Rouen in his [[de Dion-Bouton]] car, but he did not figure in the official results because his steam vehicle needed a 'stoker' and was thus ineligible. The 'official' victory was awarded to [[Albert Lemaître]] driving his 3 hp petrol engined [[Peugeot Type 5]]. * The [[internal combustion engine]] has been developed from simple gas-fuelled designs during the preceding decades to the point where several technicians such as [[Karl Benz]] in [[Mannheim]] and the partnership of [[Gottlieb Daimler]] and [[Wilhelm Maybach]] in [[Stuttgart]] have built the first true [[automobiles]] during the 1880s. Racing of horse-drawn carriages has been popular among its participants in the past and it is a natural progression to race the new automobiles.
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 17 March — [[Oxford University Boat Club|Oxford]] wins the 51st [[The Boat Race 1894|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]]
==[[Rugby football]]== '''Home Nations Championship''' * 12th [[1894 Home Nations Championship|Home Nations Championship]] series is won by [[Ireland national rugby union team|Ireland]]
==[[Speed skating]]== '''Speed Skating World Championships''' * [[1894 World Allround Speed Skating Championships|Men's All-round Champion]] – ''none declared''
==[[Tennis]]== '''England''' * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Joshua Pim]] (Ireland) defeats [[Wilfred Baddeley]] (GB) 10–8 6–2 8–6 * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Blanche Bingley Hillyard]] (GB) defeats [[Edith Austin]] (GB) 6–1 6–1 '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – [[André Vacherot]] defeats [[Gérard Brosselin]] 1–6 6–3 6–3 '''USA''' * [[US Open (tennis)|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Robert Wrenn]] defeats [[Manliffe Goodbody]] 6–8 6–1 6–4 6–4 * [[US Open (tennis)|American Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Helen Hellwig]] defeats [[Aline Terry]] 7–5 3–6 6–0 3–6 6–3
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year 1851 – 1900}}
[[Category:Sports by year]] [[Category:1894 in sports| ]]

{{Year box}} '''1919 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport. Although [[World War I]] had ended in 1918, [[1918 flu pandemic|the influenza pandemic]] and planning difficulties from the war still curtailed sport to a considerable extent.
==[[American football]]== * [[1919 Green Bay Packers season|Green Bay Packers]] established at [[Green Bay, Wisconsin]] * [[Decatur Staleys]] established at [[Decatur, Illinois]]; the club will relocate to [[Chicago]] in 1921 and rename itself [[Chicago Bears]] * [[New York Pro Football League]] holds what is believed to be the first ever [[playoff]] tournament, won by the [[1919 Buffalo Prospects season|Buffalo Prospects]] * [[Canton Bulldogs]] win [[Ohio League]] title and the de facto national championship * Most professional teams reactivate after suspending operations the year before
==[[Association football]]== '''England''' * Competitive football resumes after the end of [[World War I]] in the 1919–20 season * The [[Football League First Division|First Division]] is expanded from 20 to 22 teams; [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] is spared relegation, while [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] controversially win promotion from the [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]], despite only finishing fifth in 1915, at the expense of rivals [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]]. [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] and [[Preston North End]] are also promoted. * The [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]] is expanded from 20 teams to 22, bringing the total number of League clubs to 44. [[Glossop F.C.|Glossop]] is expelled from the league and five clubs are elected. [[Stoke City|Stoke FC]] is restored to the league while [[Coventry City]], [[South Shields F.C. (1889)|South Shields]] (membership until 1930), [[Rotherham United]] and [[West Ham United]] all join the league for the first time. * Leeds City is expelled from the Football League due to financial irregularities after the 1919–20 season has begun; [[Port Vale F.C.|Port Vale]] is elected as a late entrant and takes over Leeds City's playing record to date. '''France''' * Formation of the [[French Football Federation]] (Fédération Française de Football or FFF) '''Germany''' * [[List of German football champions|National Championship]] – ''suspended during World War I'' '''Poland''' * Formation of the [[Polish Football Association]] (Polski Związek Piłki Nożnej or PZPN)
==[[Australian rules football]]== '''[[1919 VFL season|VFL Premiership]]''' * [[Collingwood Football Club|Collingwood]] wins the 23rd [[Australian Football League|VFL]] Premiership, defeating [[Richmond Football Club|Richmond]] 11.12 (78) to 7.11 (53) at [[Melbourne Cricket Ground]] (MCG) in the [[1919 VFL Grand Final]]. '''[[South Australian National Football League|South Australian Football League]]''' * 3 May: SAFL league football resumes after three seasons of “patriotic competitions” due to [[World War I]]. * 27 September: [[Sturt Football Club|Sturt]] and [[North Adelaide Football Club|North Adelaide]] draw 5.9 (39) apiece in the [[1919 SAFL Grand Final]]. * 4 October: In a low-scoring replay, Sturt 3.5 (23) defeat North Adelaide 2.6 (18) to win their second SAFL premiership. '''[[West Australian Football League]]''' * 20 September: [[East Perth Football Club|East Perth]] 10.8 (68) defeat [[East Fremantle Football Club|East Fremantle]] 7.4 (46) to win their first WAFL premiership.
==[[Bandy]]== '''Sweden''' * [[Allsvenskan and Elitserien (bandy)|Championship final]] – [[IFK Uppsala Bandy|IFK Uppsala]] 8–2 [[IF Göta]]
==[[Baseball]]== '''World Series''' * [[1919 Cincinnati Reds season|Cincinnati Reds]] (NL) defeats [[1919 Chicago White Sox season|Chicago White Sox]] (AL) to win the [[1919 World Series]] by 5 games to 3 '''Events''' * Even before game one of this World Series, there are rumours that some White Sox players have agreed to throw the series to the Reds for payment from gamblers. This will explode a year later in the [[Black Sox Scandal]]. * [[Babe Ruth]] hits 29 [[home run]]s for the [[Boston Red Sox]], breaking the single season record of 27 set by [[Ned Williamson]] in 1884 '''Minor leagues''' * The [[Florida State League]] is founded with teams in [[Bartow, Florida|Bartow]], [[Bradenton, Florida|Bradenton]], [[Lakeland, Florida|Lakeland]], [[Orlando, Florida|Orlando]], [[Sanford, Florida|Sandford]] and [[Tampa, Florida|Tampa]] * The [[Intercounty Baseball League]] is formed in [[Ontario]], [[Canada]] with teams in Stratford, Guelph, Kitchener and Galt
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * 4 July — [[Jack Dempsey]] becomes [[World Heavyweight Champion]] by knocking out [[Jess Willard]], the defending champion, in four rounds. Dempsey becomes one of the greatest-ever boxing champions, his charisma and punching power enabling promoters to stage the first "million dollar gates". * [[Jack Britton]] regains the [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship from [[Ted "Kid" Lewis]] for the second time, this time retaining it until his defeat by [[Mickey Walker (boxer)|Mickey Walker]] in 1922. '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm Cyber Boxing Zone]</ref> * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Jess Willard]] → [[Jack Dempsey]] * [[World Light Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Battling Levinsky]] * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – [[Mike O'Dowd]] * [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship – [[Ted "Kid" Lewis]] → [[Jack Britton]] * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – [[Benny Leonard]] * [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship – [[Johnny Kilbane]] * [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship – [[Pete Herman]] * [[World Flyweight Champion]]ship – [[Jimmy Wilde]]
==[[Canadian football]]== '''Grey Cup''' * not contested
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * Very few [[first-class cricket|first-class]] matches are played worldwide during the 1918–19 season but the County Championship is reintroduced in the 1919 English season to progress the game's post-war recovery. '''England''' * [[County Championship]] – [[Yorkshire CCC|Yorkshire]] * [[Minor Counties Championship]] – ''not contested'' * Most runs – [[Jack Hobbs]] 2594 @ 60.32 (HS 205*) * Most wickets – [[Wilfred Rhodes]] 164 @ 14.42 (BB 8–44) * [[Wisden Cricketers of the Year]] – [[Andy Ducat]], [[Patsy Hendren]], [[Percy Holmes]], [[Herbert Sutcliffe]], [[Ernest Tyldesley]] '''Australia''' * [[Sheffield Shield]] – ''not contested'' * Most runs – [[Warwick Armstrong]] 249 @ 83.00 (HS 162*) * Most wickets – [[Ted McDonald]] 25 @ 15.72 (BB 8–42) '''India''' * [[Bombay Quadrangular]] – [[Europeans cricket team|Europeans]] '''New Zealand''' * [[Plunket Shield]] – [[Wellington cricket team|Wellington]] (Dec 1918 to Jan 1919) and [[Canterbury cricket team|Canterbury]] (from Jan 1919) '''South Africa''' * 18 October – With the end of World War I, first-class cricket is played in South Africa for the first time since 13 April 1914. However, the interprovincial [[SuperSport Series|Currie Cup]] does not resume until 1920–21. '''West Indies''' * [[Inter-Colonial Tournament]] – ''not contested''
==[[Cycling]]== '''[[1919 Tour de France|Tour de France]]''' * [[Firmin Lambot]] (Belgium) wins the 13th [[List of Tour de France winners|Tour de France]] '''[[1919 Giro d'Italia|Giro d'Italia]]''' * [[Costante Girardengo]]
==[[Figure skating]]== '''World Figure Skating Championships''' * The championships are not contested
==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[1919 Open Championship|British Open]] – not contested due to [[World War I]] * [[1919 U.S. Open (golf)|US Open]] – [[Walter Hagen]] * [[1919 PGA Championship|USPGA Championship]] – [[Jim Barnes]] '''Other tournaments''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – not contested due to [[World War I]] * [[United States Amateur Championship (men's golf)|US Amateur]] – [[S. Davidson Herron]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''Events''' * [[Sir Barton]] is the first horse to win the [[United States Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|United States Triple Crown]] '''England''' * [[1919 Grand National|Grand National]] – Poethlyn * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Roseway (horse)|Roseway]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[The Panther (horse)|The Panther]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Grand Parade (horse)|Grand Parade]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – [[Bayuda (horse)|Bayuda]] * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Keysoe (horse)|Keysoe]] '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – Artilleryman '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Ladder of Light '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – ''not contested'' * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – Loch Lomond '''USA''' * [[1919 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – [[Sir Barton]] * [[Preakness Stakes]] – [[Sir Barton]] * [[Belmont Stakes]] – [[Sir Barton]]
==[[Ice hockey]]== '''Stanley Cup''' * [[1918–19 Montreal Canadiens season|Montreal Canadiens]] and [[Seattle Metropolitans]] win two games each in the [[1919 Stanley Cup Finals]] before the series, held at [[Seattle]], is cancelled after all of the Montreal players contract [[Spanish flu]] '''Events''' * March 6 - [[1918–19 Montreal Canadiens season|Montreal Canadiens]] defeat [[Ottawa Senators (original)|Ottawa Senators]] in a best-of-seven series to win the [[National Hockey League]] championship. * March 14 - [[Seattle Metropolitans]] defeat [[Vancouver Millionaires]] in a two-game playoff to win the [[1919 PCHA season]] title. * [[Allan Cup]] – [[Hamilton Tigers (ice hockey)|Hamilton Tigers]] * [[1919 Memorial Cup]] - [[University of Toronto Schools]] wins the inaugural [[Memorial Cup]] for the Canadian national junior championship
==[[Motorsport]]== {{main|1919 in motorsport}}
==[[Multi-sport event]]s== '''Far Eastern Championship Games''' * Fourth [[1919 Far Eastern Championship Games|Far Eastern Championship Games]] held in [[Manila, Philippine Islands]]
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * [[The Boat Race|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]] – not contested due to [[World War I]]
==[[Rugby league]]== '''England''' * It is not possible to resume national competitions in the 1918–19 season but county leagues and cups are arranged. * [[Rugby league county leagues|Lancashire League Championship]] – [[Rochdale Hornets]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Yorkshire League Championship]] – [[Hull F.C.|Hull]] * [[RFL Lancashire Cup|Lancashire]] [[Rugby league county cups|County Cup]] – [[Rochdale Hornets]] 22–0 [[Oldham R.L.F.C.|Oldham]] * [[RFL Yorkshire Cup|Yorkshire]] [[Rugby league county cups|County Cup]] – [[Huddersfield Giants|Huddersfield]] 14–8 [[Dewsbury Rams|Dewsbury]] '''Australia''' * [[New South Wales Rugby League premiership|NSW Premiership]] – [[Balmain Tigers|Balmain]] (outright winner)
==[[Rugby union]]== '''Five Nations Championship''' * [[Six Nations Championship|Five Nations Championship]] series is not contested due to [[World War I]]. * An Inter-Services Championship is held in Great Britain between Allied Forces rugby teams. The tournament is won by the [[New Zealand Army rugby team of 1919|New Zealand Army]] team.
==[[Speed skating]]== '''Speed Skating World Championships''' * not contested due to [[World War I]]
==[[Tennis]]== '''Australia''' * [[List of Australian Open Men's Singles champions|Australian Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Algernon Kingscote]] (GB) defeats [[Eric Pockley]] (Australia) 6–4 6–0 6–3 '''England''' * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Gerald Patterson]] (Australia) defeats [[Norman Brookes]] (Australia) 6–3 7–5 6–2 * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Suzanne Lenglen]] defeats [[Dorothea Douglass Lambert Chambers]] 10–8 4–6 9–7 '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – not contested due to [[World War I]] * [[List of French Open Women's Singles champions|French Women's Singles Championship]] – not contested due to [[World War I]] '''USA''' * [[US Open (tennis)|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Bill Johnston (tennis player)|Bill Johnston]] (USA) defeats [[Bill Tilden]] (USA) 6–4 6–4 6–3 * [[US Open (tennis)|American Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Hazel Hotchkiss Wightman]] (USA) defeats [[Marion Zinderstein]] (USA) 6–1 6–2 '''Davis Cup''' * [[1919 International Lawn Tennis Challenge]] – {{davis|Australasia}} 4–1 {{davis|GBR}} at Double Bay Grounds (grass) [[Sydney]], [[Australia]]

revision.text:
'''1955 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.<ref>{{cite book|last=Nite|first=Norm N.|title=Rock On Almanac: The First Four Decades of Rock ‘n’ Roll: A Chronology|edition=2nd|year=1992|publisher=Harper Collins|location=New York|isbn=0-06-273157-2|page=26}}</ref>
{{Year box}}
==[[American football]]== * [[1955 NFL Championship Game|NFL Championship]] – [[Cleveland Browns]] win 38-14 over the [[Los Angeles Rams]] * [[1955 Rose Bowl|Rose Bowl]] (1954 season): ** The [[Ohio State Buckeyes]] win 20-7 over the [[USC Trojans|Southern California Trojans]] to win the [[AP Poll]] national championship
==[[Association football]]==
===England=== * [[Football League First Division|First Division]] – [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] win the [[1954–55 in English football|1954–55]] title * [[FA Cup]] – [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] beat [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] 3-1
==[[Athletics (track and field)|Athletics]]== * March 12 to 16 – [[Athletics at the 1955 Pan American Games]] in [[Mexico City]]
==[[Australian rules football]]== * [[Victorian Football League (1897–1989)|Victorian Football League]] ** [[Melbourne Football Club|Melbourne]] wins the 59th VFL Premiership, defeating [[Collingwood Football Club|Collingwood]] 8.16 (64) to 5.6 (36) [[1955 VFL Grand Final|in the Grand Final]]. ** [[Brownlow Medal]] awarded to [[Fred Goldsmith (Australian rules footballer)|Fred Goldsmith]] ([[Sydney Swans|South Melbourne]]) * [[South Australian National Football League]] ** April 30: [[West Torrens Football Club|West Torrens]] 9.12 (66) draws [[Norwood Football Club|Norwood]] 8.18 (66) at [[Thebarton Oval]]. It is the first senior SANFL drawn match since [[West Adelaide Football Club|West Adelaide]] 15.14 (104) drew [[Port Adelaide Magpies Football Club|with Port Adelaide]] 16.8 (104) on 24 May 1941.<ref>{{cite news|last=Jervis|first=Lawrie|title=Redlegs, North Have Played Many Draws|work=News|location=Adelaide|date=1954-08-31|page=43}}</ref> The intervening 788-game gap<ref>This excludes the wartime competition of 1942 to 1944.</ref> constitutes easily the longest non-occurrence of draws in SANFL history and is twice as long as the V/AFL or VFA record, but has been bettered twice in the WAFL. ** October 1: Port Adelaide 15.11 (101) defeats Norwood 5.8 (38) for their second consecutive premiership * [[West Australian Football League]] ** October 8: [[Perth Football Club|Perth]] 11.11 (77) defeat [[East Fremantle Football Club|East Fremantle]] 11.9 (75) for their first premiership since 1907 in champion ruckman [[Merv McIntosh]]'s final match.
==[[Bandy]]== * [[Federation of International Bandy]] inaugurated at [[Stockholm]] by Finland, Norway, Sweden and the USSR. The Soviet Union now adopts the international rules of the game developed in England in the 19th century.
==[[Baseball]]== * [[Philadelphia Athletics]] move to Kansas City, Missouri and become the [[Kansas City Athletics]] * April 23 – [[1955 Chicago White Sox season|The White Sox]] tally a franchise record 29 runs at [[1955 Kansas City Athletics season|Kansas City]]. [[Sherm Lollar]] is 5-for-6 with a pair of home runs and five RBI, while reserve outfielder [[Bob Nieman]] and infielder [[Walt Dropo]] drive in seven runs apiece, and [[Chico Carrasquel]] hits 5-for-6 with five runs in the 29-6 victory over the Athletics * [[1955 World Series|World Series]] – October 4 – [[1955 Brooklyn Dodgers season|The Brooklyn Dodgers]] win 4 games to 3 over [[1955 New York Yankees season|the New York Yankees]]; Series MVP is pitcher [[Johnny Podres]], Brooklyn
==[[Basketball]]== * [[NCAA Men's Basketball Championship]] – San Francisco wins 76-73 over La Salle * [[1955 NBA Finals|NBA Finals]] – [[1954–55 Syracuse Nationals season|The Syracuse Nationals]] beat [[1954–55 Fort Wayne Pistons season|the Fort Wayne Pistons]] 4 games to 3 to win the [[1954–55 NBA season|NBA title]] * [[Eurobasket 1955]], the ninth European basketball championship, is won by [[Hungary national basketball team|Hungary]] * March 1 – [[Allen Fieldhouse]] opens at the [[University of Kansas]] as the Jayhawks defeat [[Kansas State University|Kansas State]] * Bayi Basketball Club, officially founded in [[Ningbo]], [[Zhejiang Province]].(as predecessor for [[Bayi Rockets]], as known well for professional basketball club in China){{citation needed|date=December 2016}}
==[[Boxing]]== * March 12 to 16 – [[Boxing at the 1955 Pan American Games]] in Mexico City * September 21 – In New York City, [[Rocky Marciano]] knocks out the light-heavyweight champion [[Archie Moore]] in the 9th round to retain his World Heavyweight Championship belt
==[[Canadian football]]== * [[Grey Cup]] – [[Edmonton Eskimos]] won 34-19 over the [[Montreal Alouettes]]
==[[Cycling]]== * [[1955 Giro d'Italia|Giro d'Italia]] won by [[Fiorenzo Magni]] of Italy * [[1955 Tour de France|Tour de France]] – [[Louison Bobet]] of France * [[UCI Road World Championships – Men's road race]] – [[Stan Ockers]] of Belgium
==[[Figure skating]]== * [[1954 World Figure Skating Championships|World Figure Skating Championships]] – ** Men's champion: [[Hayes Alan Jenkins]], United States ** Ladies' champion: [[Tenley Albright]], United States ** Pair skating champions: [[Frances Dafoe]] & [[Norris Bowden]], Canada ** Ice dancing champions: [[Jean Westwood (figure skater)|Jean Westwood]] & [[Lawrence Demmy]], Great Britain
==[[Golf]]== '''Men's professional''' * [[1955 Masters Tournament|Masters Tournament]] – [[Cary Middlecoff]] * [[1955 U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]] – [[Jack Fleck]] * [[1955 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Peter Thomson (golfer)|Peter Thomson]] * [[1955 PGA Championship|PGA Championship]] – [[Doug Ford (golfer)|Doug Ford]] * [[PGA Tour]] money leader – [[Julius Boros]] – $63,122 * [[1955 Ryder Cup|Ryder Cup]] – United States team wins 8-4 over the British team. '''Men's amateur''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – [[Joe Conrad]] * [[U.S. Amateur]] – [[Harvie Ward]] '''Women's professional''' * The [[LPGA]] launches the new [[LPGA Championship]] annual tournament. * [[Women's Western Open]] – [[Patty Berg]] * [[1955 LPGA Championship|LPGA Championship]] – [[Beverly Hanson]] * [[1955 U.S. Women's Open Golf Championship|U.S. Women's Open]] – [[Fay Crocker]] * [[Titleholders Championship]] – [[Patty Berg]] * [[LPGA|LPGA Tour]] money leader – [[Patty Berg]] – $16,492
==[[Harness racing]]== * The first [[Cane Pace]] is held at Yonkers Raceway. * [[Little Brown Jug (horse racing)|Little Brown Jug]] for pacers won by [[Quick Chief]] * [[Cane Pace]] won by [[Quick Chief]] * The [[Triple Crown of Harness Racing for Trotters|United States Trotting Triple Crown races]] are established. [[Scott Frost (horse)|Scott Frost]] will win the first ever crown. *# [[Hambletonian Stakes|Hambletonian]] – [[Scott Frost (horse)|Scott Frost]] *# [[Yonkers Trot]] – [[Scott Frost (horse)|Scott Frost]] *# [[Kentucky Futurity]] – [[Scott Frost (horse)|Scott Frost]] * [[Australian Inter Dominion Harness Racing Championship]] – ** Pacers: [[Tactician (horse)|Tactician]] ** Trotters: [[Battle Cry (horse)|Battle Cry]]
==[[Horse racing]]== * August 31 – In one of the most famous match races in [[thoroughbred]] racing history, [[Nashua (horse)|Nashua]] beats [[Swaps (horse)|Swaps]] at Washington Park racetrack, Swaps only loss in nine starts as a three-year-old. Nashua's owner-breeder, [[William Woodward, Jr.]], dreams of owning an [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] winner, and plans to send Nashua to England to train toward that goal but is shot dead by his wife on October 31 before he can proceed. '''Steeplechases''' * [[Cheltenham Gold Cup]] – [[Gay Donald]] * [[1955 Grand National|Grand National]] – [[Quare Times]] '''Flat races''' * Australia – [[Melbourne Cup]] won by [[Toparoa]] * Canada – [[Queen's Plate]] won by [[Ace Marine]] * France – [[Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe]] won by [[Ribot (horse)|Ribot]] * Ireland – [[Irish Derby Stakes]] won by [[Panaslipper]] * [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|English Triple Crown Races]]: *# [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Our Babu]] *# [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Phil Drake]] *# [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Meld (horse)|Meld]] * [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|United States Triple Crown Races]]: *# [[1955 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – [[Swaps (horse)|Swaps]] *# [[Preakness Stakes]] – [[Nashua (horse)|Nashua]] *# [[Belmont Stakes]] – [[Nashua (horse)|Nashua]]
==[[Ice hockey]]== * [[Art Ross Trophy]] as the [[National Hockey League|NHL]]'s leading scorer during the regular season: [[Bernie Geoffrion|Bernie "Boom-Boom" Geoffrion]], [[Montreal Canadiens]] * [[Hart Memorial Trophy]] for the [[National Hockey League|NHL]]'s Most Valuable Player: [[Ted Kennedy (ice hockey)|Ted Kennedy]], [[Toronto Maple Leafs]] * [[1955 Stanley Cup Finals|Stanley Cup]] – [[Detroit Red Wings]] win 4 games to 3 over the [[Montreal Canadiens]] * [[World Hockey Championship]] – Men's champion: Canada's [[Penticton Vees]] win 5-0 over the [[Soviet Union|USSR]] * [[NCAA Men's Ice Hockey Championship]] – [[University of Michigan]] Wolverines defeat [[Colorado College]] Tigers 5-3 in [[Colorado Springs]]
==[[Motorsport]]== {{main|1955 in motorsport|List of 1955 motorsport champions}}
==[[Rugby league]]== *[[1955–56 European Rugby League Championship]] *[[1955 New Zealand rugby league season]] *[[1955 NSWRFL season]] *[[1954–55 Northern Rugby Football League season]] / [[1955–56 Northern Rugby Football League season]]
==[[Rugby union]]== * 61st [[Six Nations Championship|Five Nations Championship]] series is shared by [[France national rugby union team|France]] and [[Wales national rugby union team|Wales]]
==[[Snooker]]== * [[World Snooker Championship]] – [[Fred Davis (snooker player)|Fred Davis]] beats [[John Pulman]] 37-34
==[[Tennis]]== '''Australia''' * [[List of Australian Open Men's Singles champions|Australian Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Ken Rosewall]] (Australia) defeats [[Lew Hoad]] (Australia) 9–7, 6–4, 6–4 * [[List of Australian Open Women's Singles champions|Australian Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Beryl Penrose Collier]] (Australia) defeats [[Thelma Coyne Long]] (Australia) 6–4, 6–3 '''England''' * [[List of Wimbledon Gentlemen's Singles champions|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Tony Trabert]] (USA) defeats [[Kurt Nielsen]] (Denmark) 6–3, 7–5, 6–1 * [[List of Wimbledon Ladies' Singles champions|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Louise Brough Clapp]] (USA) defeats [[Beverly Baker Fleitz]] (USA) 7–5, 8–6 '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – * [[List of French Open Women's Singles champions|French Women's Singles Championship]] – '''USA''' * [[List of US Open Men's Singles champions|American Men's Singles Championship]] – * [[List of US Open Women's Singles champions|American Women's Singles Championship]] – '''Davis Cup''' * [[1955 Davis Cup]] – {{davis|AUS}} 5–0 {{davis|USA|1912}} at [[West Side Tennis Club]] (grass) New York City, United States
==[[Volleyball]]== * March 16 to 20 – [[Volleyball at the 1955 Pan American Games]] in Mexico City ** '''Men's Tournament''' *** Gold Medal: USA *** Silver Medal: Mexico *** Bronze Medal: Brazil ** '''Women's Tournament''' *** Gold Medal: Mexico *** Silver Medal: USA *** Bronze Medal: Brazil
==[[Multi-sport event]]s== * March 12 to 16 – Second [[1955 Pan American Games|Pan American Games]] held in [[Mexico City]], [[Mexico]] * Second [[Mediterranean Games]] held in [[Barcelona, Spain]]
==Awards== * [[Associated Press Athlete of the Year#List of award winners|Associated Press Male Athlete of the Year]] – [[Howard "Hopalong" Cassady]], [[College football]] * [[Associated Press Athlete of the Year#List of award winners|Associated Press Female Athlete of the Year]] – [[Patty Berg]], [[LPGA|LPGA golf]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year 1951 – 2000}}
[[Category:Sports by year]] [[Category:1955 in sports| ]]

The '''anti-jock movement''' is a loosely organized [[cyber-]][[social movement|movement]] consisting of similarly themed [[website]]s, whose goal is to challenge the perceived [[culture|cultural]] dominance of [[institution]]alized competitive [[sports]] and to raise issues of the perceived detrimental effects of such a dominance. In this regard, the term "[[jock (athlete)|jock]]" is used in its sense of "[[stereotypical]] [[sportsperson|athlete]]," although websites constituent of the Anti-jock Movement often use the term to distinguish negative or excessive interest in sports, from common or positive athletic endeavor. The stereotypical athlete can be defined as an individual who uses his or her athletic ability or abilities in an effort to gain social capital. His or her identity is intertwined with their athletic endeavor and as a result they are unable to connect with individuals who do not participate in athletics.{{cite journal|jstor=20054158|title=Ethnography, the Internet, and Youth Culture: Strategies for Examining Social Resistance and "Online-Offline" Relationships|journal=Canadian Journal of Education / Revue canadienne de l'éducation|first=Brian|last=Wilson|date=1 January 2006|publisher=|volume=29|issue=1|pages=307–328|doi=10.2307/20054158}} In the decade following the year 2000, increasing recognition has been given to the existence of a movement consisting of "a group of self-described [[marginalized]] youth [who] constructed and sustained anti-jock websites, where they articulated 'dissatisfaction with and anger toward institutions that uncritically adulate hyper-masculine/high contact sport culture and the athletes who are part of this culture (i.e., the ‘jocks’)'”.Stack, M., & Kelly, D. M. (2006). "The Popular Media, Education, and Resistance". ''Canadian Journal of Education'', 29(1), 5-26. This "group of self-described marginalized youth" identify with the individuals who feel as though they have been marginalized by "stereotypical athlete". As a whole, the group of young people who created the anti-jock cyber movement were not students who participated in athletics. The anti-jock cyber-movement was created as support to those who feel as though they have been tormented by the 'jocks' and was initially created as a support group. As the anti-jock movement gained support, it was took on a more negative perspective against the "stereotypical athlete".{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ush9CBSByIcC|title=Tribal Play: Subcultural Journeys Through Sport|last=Young|first=Kevin|date=2008-01-01|publisher=Emerald Group Publishing|isbn=978-0-7623-1293-1|language=en}} Such has been cited as an act of resistance against the dominant [[mass media|media]] and cultural [[paradigm]]. == Recognition == One of the most cited articles giving recognition to the existence of an anti-jock cyber movement is a 2002 article published by Brian Wilson (an assistant professor of Cultural Studies and Sociology, University of British Columbia) in the ''Sociology of Sport Journal'', titled "The 'Anti-Jock' Movement: Reconsidering Youth Resistance, Masculinity and Sport Culture in the Age of the Internet".Wilson, Brian. (2002). "The 'Anti-Jock' Movement: Reconsidering Youth Resistance, Masculinity and Sport Culture in the Age of the Internet". ''Sociology of Sport Journal'', 19(2), 207-234. In the course of the article, Wilson described the movement as follows:
The anti-jock movement is group of self-described "marginalized youth" who, through the production and consumption of anti-jock Websites, express dissatisfaction with and anger toward institutions that uncritically adulate hyper-masculine/high-contact sport culture and the athletes who are part of this culture (i.e. the "jocks"). Through these Websites, strategies of resistance against the "pro-jock" establishment are offered.
After analyzing the content of various "Anti-Jock" websites, Wilson concluded that
In one sense, the anti-jock Websites can be viewed, together, as a new social movement according to Harvey and Houle's definition. That is to say, they are not linked to specific economic interests, they are working toward change in society's (pro-jock) values, and (arguably), anti-jocks are working toward a better society where males and females are nor subject to the domination of the interests of a masculinist sport culture and jocks.
Since its 2002 publication, Wilson's article has been often cited with reference to the existence of the Anti-Jock Movement.See, for example, ''Deviance and Social Control in Sport'' by Michael Atkinson, Kevin Young; Human Kinetics Publishers, 2008. See also, ''Sport in a Changing World'' by Howard L. Nixon, Paradigm Publishers, 2007. == Constituent websites == Professor Brian Wilson, in his article "The 'Anti-Jock' Movement: Reconsidering Youth Resistance, Masculinity and Sport Culture in the Age of the Internet", detailed two basic types of websites which are common within the Anti-Jock [[cyberculture|cyber]] movement. First, [[webzine]]s devoted to opposition of the jock culture. These sites often include suggestions for activism and action against the jock establishment. Professor Wilson, referred specifically to two such sites: [http://members.tripod.com/~lucas94/index-5.html ''Spoilsports''], and the now defunct [https://web.archive.org/web/20020106215146/http://www.hsunderground.com/index.html ''High School Underground'']. There are however, other such sites, such as the [http://www.sportssuck.org/ ''International I Hate Sports Club''], which have similar objectives and content. Second, there are personal websites, consisting of personal [[Monologue|rants]] criticizing the jock establishment, "personal interest" websites which include personal concerns which include criticism about jock culture, and third, personal sites that devote themselves exclusively to anti-jock statements. A large part of the anti-jock movement began as a result of specific individuals who felt marginalized by stereotypical athletes and used the internet to voice their frustrations. In turn, other individuals who were experiencing the same frustrations found support within this cyber-movement. == See also == *[[Sociology of sport]] == References == {{Reflist}} {{Refbegin}} * James L. Shulman & William G. Bowen. (2007) The Game of Life: College Sports and Educational Values{{Clarify|date=December 2011|reason=This is not a proper reference citation. Use [[Template:Cite web]] or similar to provide source details. Use inline in the article (see [[WP:CITE]]) to source the specific facts provided by this reference.}} {{Refend}} == External links == *[http://www.sportssuck.org/ The International I Hate Sports Club] *[http://members.tripod.com/~lucas94/index-5.html Spoil Sports] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20020106215146/http://www.hsunderground.com/index.html High School Underground (from archive)] *[http://members.tripod.com/~lucas94/ribboncam.html Anti-Jock Purple Ribbon Campaign] *[http://www.humankinetics.com/SSJ/viewarticle.cfm?jid=X7whb8t3X7wwv6mqX8gpn8nRX2qab74CX4xd63xaX6&view=art&aid=1767&site=X7whb8t3X7wwv6mqX8gpn8nRX2qab74CX4xd63xaX6 Article:Wilson, Brian. (2002). The “Anti-Jock” Movement: Reconsidering Youth Resistance, Masculinity and Sport Culture in the Age of the Internet. Sociology of Sport Journal, 19(2), 207-234.] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20081010152458/http://www.csse.ca/CJE/Articles/FullText/CJE29-1/CJE29-1-stackkelly.pdf Article: Stack, M., & Kelly, D. M. (2006). The Popular Media, Education, and Resistance. Canadian Journal of Education, 29(1), 5-26.] [[Category:Nerd culture]] [[Category:Sports culture]]

{{original research|date=December 2009}}
A '''bench-clearing brawl''', sometimes known as a '''basebrawl''' or a '''rhubarb''', is a form of ritualistic fighting that occurs in sports, most notably [[baseball]] and [[ice hockey]], in which every player on both teams leave their [[Dugout (baseball)|dugout]]s, [[bullpen]]s or benches, and charge the playing area in order to fight one another or try to break up a fight.
==Baseball== [[File:Massive fenway brawl.jpg|thumb|Bench-clearing brawl at [[Fenway Park]] because of [[Coco Crisp]] getting hit by a pitch by [[James Shields (baseball)|James Shields]].]] In [[baseball]], brawls are usually the result of escalating infractions, often stemming from a player being [[Hit by pitch|hit by a pitch]], or an altercation between a [[baserunner]] and [[infielder]] stemming from excessive contact in an attempted [[tag out]] (such as a runner crashing into the [[catcher (baseball)|catcher]] at home plate in an attempt to dislodge the ball, which is an [[interference (baseball)|offensive interference]] violation that may result in ejection). They are also known to occur when a batter [[charging the mound|charges the mound]]. However, few bench-clearing brawls result in serious injury, as in most cases, no punches are thrown, and the action is limited to pushing and shoving.
Unlike most other team sports, in which teams usually have an equivalent number of players on the field at any given time, in baseball the hitting team is at a numerical disadvantage, with a maximum of five players (batter, up to three runners, and on-deck batter) and two base coaches on the field at any time, compared to the fielding team's nine players. For this reason, leaving the dugout to join a fight is generally considered acceptable in that it results in numerical equivalence on the field, a fairer fight, and a generally neutral outcome, as in most cases, managers and/or umpires will intervene to restore order and resume the game. In at least one case (the infamous [[Ten Cent Beer Night]] promotion), one team (the Cleveland Indians, who were the home team) left its dugout to defend the other (the Texas Rangers, the visiting team) from its own fans (who had [[pitch invasion|stormed the field]]).
===Penalty=== Depending on the severity of the [[unsportsmanlike conduct]], an [[umpire (baseball)|umpire]] may or may not [[ejection (sports)|eject]] a brawl's participants. Since a bench-clearing brawl by definition involves ''everyone'' on both teams, it is exceedingly unlikely that all participants will be ejected, but the player or players responsible for the precipitating event are often ejected.<ref>{{cite|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/mlb/downloads/y2011/Official_Baseball_Rules.pdf|work=Major League Baseball|title=The Official Baseball Rules|accessdate=2013-04-06}}</ref> Fines and suspensions generally result and are issued at a later date.
==Ice hockey== [[File:ThorntonfightingBrookbank.jpg|thumb|[[Shawn Thornton]] fighting [[Wade Brookbank]].]]
[[Fighting in ice hockey]] by [[enforcer (ice hockey)|enforcers]] is an established, if unofficial, part of the sport (especially in [[North America]], where the penalty rules are more permissive); the general procedure in a one-on-one fight is to let it pan out and then send both players to the [[penalty box]] with five-minute [[Major penalty|major penalties]]. Escalations beyond isolated fights, such as line brawls between groups of players on the ice, are [[violence in ice hockey|prohibited]], meaning bench-clearing brawls will result in serious consequences. General brawls can result in players being assessed [[game misconduct]] penalties and [[ejection (sports)|ejected]] from the game. This is especially the case if a player leaves the bench or [[penalty box]] to join a fight.
As in baseball, hockey brawls usually result from escalating infractions; in this case, dangerous hits, excessive post-whistle roughness, taking shots after the whistle, attacking the [[goaltender]], and hatred from competition in a game with a significant amount of inter-player violence, all contribute to bench-clearing brawls.
In the [[National Hockey League]] the penalties include, in addition to in-game penalties, an automatic 10-game suspension and a fine of $10,000<ref>[http://www.nhl.com/ice/page.htm?id=26481 ''Rule 70.10 – Leaving the Players' or Penalty Bench''] in the NHL Rulebook</ref> for the first player to leave his bench or the penalty box to participate in a brawl; for the second player to leave his bench or the penalty box, the penalties include, in addition to in-game penalties, an automatic five-game suspension and a fine of $5,000.
The [[International Ice Hockey Federation]] rules prescribe a double minor penalty plus a game misconduct penalty for the first player to leave the bench during an altercation and a misconduct penalty for other such players;<ref>[http://www.iihf.com/iihf-home/sport/iihf-rule-book.html IIHF Rule Book 2006–2010], Rule 564 – Players Leaving the Benches During an Altercation, p. 101</ref> a player who leaves the penalty box during an altercation is assessed a minor penalty plus a game misconduct penalty.<ref>[http://www.iihf.com/iihf-home/sport/iihf-rule-book.html IIHF Rule Book 2006–2010], Rule 563 – Players Leaving the Penalty Bench, p. 99</ref> In addition to these penalties for leaving the bench, all players engaging in a fight may be penalized.<ref>[http://www.iihf.com/iihf-home/sport/iihf-rule-book.html IIHF Rule Book 2006–2010], Rule 528 – Fisticuffs or Roughing, p. 73</ref>
One of the more notable incidents was the [[Punch-up in Piestany]], a game between Canada and the Soviet Union during the [[1987 World Junior Ice Hockey Championships]]. The game was rougher and more dangerous than is generally accepted, and with 6:07 left in the second period, a wild fight broke out between Pavel Kostichkin and [[Theoren Fleury]], causing both teams to leave the benches for 20 minutes. The officials ordered that the arena lights be turned out, but to no avail, and the [[IIHF]] eventually declared the game void. Both teams were ejected from the tournament, costing Canada a potential gold medal, and the Canadian team, disgusted at what they perceived to be a conspiracy against them, chose to leave rather than stay for the end-of-tournament festivities, from which the Soviet team were banned.
A notable [[KHL]] bench-clearing brawl saw all the players of [[Avangard Omsk]] and [[Vityaz Chekhov]], except for the goaltenders, fighting at 3 minutes and 34 seconds. The referees penalized all the players who were involved in the brawl, and called the game due to lack of players; the teams were fined 5.7 million [[Russian ruble|rubles]] and had the game counted as a double loss.
==Other sports== Bench-clearing brawls have also been known to occur in other sports, and officials in those sports have been cracking down on such brawls; in 1995, the [[National Basketball Association]] changed the penalty for leaving the bench to participate in a brawl from a $500 fine to an automatic one-game suspension.
In 2010, the [[Northern Territory Football League]] in Australia ruled that any player found to have left the interchange bench to participate in a melee would be ejected from that match; they would also have their melee fine increased by 25% and receive an automatic one-game suspension.
Bench-clearing brawls do not occur very often in [[gridiron football]]. All levels of the game penalize any "substitute who leaves the team box during a fight" (as it is worded in the high school rule books) with automatic ejection and possible further sanctions depending on the league, and the amount of equipment a football player wears increases the risk for injury in a brawl greatly. In addition, on-field umpires and referees move in immediately to break up fights, and any contact by a team member against an official will draw the immediate penalty of ejection from the game, with further sanctions by league officials virtually certain, along with [[Penalty (gridiron football)#List of penalties|on-field penalties]] that move the ball closer or farther from the goal line depending on the team sanctioned, hurting the team's winning chances far more than in other sports. One notable brawl at the college level was [[FIU–Miami football brawl|between Florida International University and the University of Miami]], where tough talk between two [[crosstown rivalry|crosstown rivals]] escalated into a brawl with severe consequences for FIU.
At least two bench-clearing brawls have taken place in the Lingerie Football League, since renamed the [[Legends Football League]]. The first came in 2009 between the [[Miami Caliente]] and the [[New York Majesty]]; that brawl eventually led to the Majesty suspending operations. Another occurred during the December 9, 2011 LFL game between the [[Toronto Triumph]] and the [[Philadelphia Passion]]. It was unclear what punishment either team would face as Toronto was already using [[replacement player]]s due to a mass walkout of the original team earlier in the year.
===High school and scholastic sports=== Bench-clearing brawls are prohibited in scholastic competition with the [[National Federation of State High School Associations]] specifying the penalty for leaving the bench area to participate in a fight in any sanctioned sport as an automatic [[ejection (sports)|ejection]] and, if actively involved in a fight, an automatic [[suspension (punishment)|suspension]]. In addition, school administrators may implement more severe penalties such as disqualification from activities, academic suspension or [[Expulsion (education)|expulsion]].<ref>{{cite|url=http://www.nfhs.org/vango/custom/resourcelibrary/|title=NFHS Resource Library|work=National Federation of State High School Associations|accessdate=2013-04-06}}</ref> In more severe instances, entire schools can face sanctions from their state's athletic association, ranging from letters of reprimand, forfeiture of contests, withholding of travel expenses and extended suspensions of players and coaches to, in the most severe cases, cancellation of a team's entire season or suspension of a school's entire athletic program.
==See also== {{Portal|Baseball|Basketball|Ice hockey|Sports}} * [[Red Wings–Avalanche brawl]] * [[Pacers–Pistons brawl]] * [[Knicks–Nuggets brawl]] * [[Philippines–Australia basketball brawl]] * [[2011 Crosstown Shootout brawl]] * [[Violence in sports]] * [[Pine Tar Incident]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{baseball}}

revision.text:
{{undisclosed paid|date=July 2017}} {{Orphan|date=June 2014}}
{{Infobox company | name = BodyCode Training System | logo = File:BodyCode_Training_System.png | logo_caption = | image = | image_caption = | type = | industry = | founder = Pino Carbone | location_city = | location_country = | area_served = | key_people = | products = Exercise equipment, accessories, | services = | parent = | divisions = | homepage = {{URL|www.bodycodesystem.com}} | footnotes = | intl = | bodystyle = }} '''BodyCode Training System''' is a technique for evaluating and correcting movement patterns using specifically designed equipment. It deals with how people construct awkward postures, and how to maintain and apply intervention strategies to correct them. It was developed in the 1990s by Pino Carbone.<ref name=EE/> It is mainly used by dancers and athletes but can be used by anybody. It is among the curricula of [[Boston Ballet|Boston Ballet School]], the [[National Ballet of China|Chinese National Ballet]], [[English National Ballet School]], and other private ballet school.<ref name=TR/>
BodyCode Training System includes [[Aerobic exercise|aerobic]] and [[Anaerobic exercise|anaerobic activities]], [[Isometric exercise|isometric]] and [[Isotonic (exercise physiology)|isotonic exercises]] and proprioceptive movement, as well as static and dynamic activities.<ref name=EE/> The specific set of exercises suitable for an individual is designed by a trainer after a postural examination.<ref name=TV>{{cite web|url=http://www.telva.com/2008/05/27/estarbienfitness/1211878356.html|title= Body-Code|publisher=Telva|accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref> In 2004, Carbone was awarded Geneva’s international inventor’s prize for designing BodyCode equipment called SpheralMind.<ref name=TF/>
== History == BodyCode Training System was developed by Pino Carbone. Carbone was a professional dancer for several years before he had an accident in the 1980s during the rehearsal of a ballet that affected his back and resulted in a [[Spinal disc herniation|herniated disc]]. Following his injury, he had to incorporate acupuncture, Pilates, Gyrotonics [[yoga]], [[massage]] and [[physical therapy]] in his regimen in order to continue with his dancing. At that time, he started research to develop a training system for strengthening and stretching muscles without the risk of injury that he could use.<ref name=TR>{{cite web|url=http://mujer.terra.es/muj/articulo/html/mu225597.htm|title= Body Code: cuerpo y men| publisher=Terra|accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref> After several years of research and work, he developed the BodyCode System in the 1990s.<ref name=ABC>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.es/hemeroteca/historico-19-01-2008/abc/Sabados/%C2%A1a-moverse!-body-code-en-forma-sin-desgaste_1641570674316.html |title=¡A moverse! Body Code, en forma sin desgaste|publisher=ABC.es|accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref> According to Carbone, he was tired of dancing in pain. He wanted to settle down and open his own studio. By then he was already doing [[Gyrotonics]] with Juliu Horvath, in New York City, so he decided to open his first studio in [[Florence]] and offer training that combined principles of yoga, dance, Gyrotonics and [[Pilates]].<ref name=TF/>
Although Carbone primarily worked with dancers and athletes, in the early 1990s, he began collaborating with orthopaedics, neurosurgeons and other medical specialists.<ref name=PL/><ref name=RR>{{cite web|url=http://www.reportpistoia.com/archivio-benessere/6954-che-cosa-e-il-metodo-bodycode.html|title= Che cosa è il metodo Bodycode|publisher=Report Pistoia|accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref> Currently, it is taught in dance programs worldwide.<ref name=PL/>
== Principles == BodyCode exercises are based on the principles of harmonizing body and mind. The basis of the method is to restore the physical as well as mental balance. Theories of BodyCode have oriental roots and are related to [[acupuncture]], yoga, dance and [[feng shui]].<ref name=EL>{{cite web|url=http://www.elle.es/belleza/cara-cuerpo/en-forma-con-body-code|title=La nueva disciplina para poner a punto cuerpo y mente|publisher=Elle Spanish|accessdate=22 February 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140227175444/http://www.elle.es/belleza/cara-cuerpo/en-forma-con-body-code#|archive-date=2014-02-27|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> It draws influences from Gyrotonics as well as Pilates.<ref name=TF>{{cite web|url=http://www.theflorentine.net/articles/article-view.asp?issuetocId=1642|title= An Interview with Pino Carbone|publisher=The Florentine|accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref>
BodyCode also employs basic principles of traditional gymnastics and dance movements. The purpose of the method is to improve the body movement and postural alignment.<ref name=TR/><ref>{{cite news|publisher=Elle Spanish|title=El Codigo Da Pino|date=September 2008|pages=233, 234}}</ref> BodyCode Training System includes [[Aerobic exercise|aerobic]] and [[Anaerobic exercise|anaerobic activities]], [[Isometric exercise|isometric]] and [[Isotonic (exercise physiology)|isotonic exercises]] and proprioception exercises as well as static and dynamic activities.<ref name=EE/> It deals with how people construct awkward postures, and how to maintain and apply intervention strategies to correct them.<ref name=PL/>
== Approach and equipment == There are various pieces of equipment designed by Carbone for performing different body movements. Some of these are handmade<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vanitatis.com/cache/2008/09/18/tendencias_30_bodycode_fusion_entre_cuerpo_mente.html|title=BodyCode o la fusión entre cuerpo y mente|publisher=Vanitatis|accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref> and include ''Pegasus'', ''SpheralMind'', ''ProArch'', ''Geometrix'', ''Elvis'', ''Dance Ruler'' and ''MasterStretch''.<ref name=TV/> ''MasterStretch'' is developed for improving the flexibility of the spine and coordination and proprioception.<ref name=EE>{{cite web|url=http://ecodiario.eleconomista.es/evasion/gente-estilo/noticias/480996/04/08/Body-Code-la-manera-de-hacer-ejercicio-en-el-siglo-XXI.html |title=Body Code, la manera de hacer ejercicio en el siglo XXI|publisher=El Economista|accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref>
Carbone holds the trademark for BodyCode system as well as several equipment design patents. Only legally authorized instructors can lawfully provide BodyCode training. Before beginning BodyCode training, an individual's posture and balance are evaluated in order to determine their weaknesses and their requirements. Following this assessment, the instructor prepares a program that is focused on rebalancing the body.<ref name=ABC/> The first phase of evaluating body posture is called ''decoding'' and the second phase of training to improve balance is called ''coding''.<ref name=PL>{{cite news|publisher=Pilates Lifestyle|title=Body Talk – Cracking the Code of Movement|first=Heidi|last=Dvorak}}</ref>
=== Work in === BodyCode uses the concept of work-in as opposed to work-out. According to this concept, the physical imbalance, stress, trauma, bad habits and poor posture should not be corrected externally but internally. The individuals while practising this technique are taught to be aware of their body characteristics and how to train it.<ref name=PL/>
== In the media == The BodyCode System was featured in Marie Claire Spanish in the article ''Top ten en gimnasios - El más barato (Top ten cheapest gym equipment)''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marie-claire.es/belleza/cuerpo/fotos/fotos-gimansios-10/fotos-10-gimnasios-10___12219|title=Top ten en gimnasios - El más barato|publisher=Marie Claire|accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Gyrotonic]]
== References == {{reflist|2}}
== External links == {{official website|www.bodycodesystem.com}}
[[Category:Physical exercise]]

revision.comment: /* Typical activities in a circuit training */Typo
revision.text:
'''Circuit training''' is a form of body conditioning or [[endurance training]] or [[resistance training]] using high-intensity. It targets strength building or muscular endurance. An exercise "circuit" is one completion of all prescribed exercises in the program. When one circuit is complete, one begins the first exercise again for the next circuit. Traditionally, the time between exercises in circuit training is short, often with rapid movement to the next exercise.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sportireland.ie/Coaching-Ireland/Publications-/Circuit-Training.pdf|title=CIRCUIT TRAINING. Development of Strength & Conditioning|last=Comyns|first=Tom|date=|website=Coaching Ireland|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=19 July 2018}}</ref>
The program was developed by R.E. Morgan and G.T. Anderson in 1953 at the [[University of Leeds]] in [[England]].<ref name="UNM">{{cite web | url=http://www.unm.edu/~lkravitz/Article%20folder/circuits05.html | title=New Insights into Circuit Training| accessdate =2006-11-16| last=Kraviz| first=Len| work=| publisher=University of New Mexico| date=1996-01-01}}</ref>
==Typical activities in a circuit training== A circuit should work each section of the body individually. Typical activities include:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brianmac.co.uk/circuit.htm|title=Circuit Training|author=Brian Mackenzie|work=brianmac.co.uk}}</ref>
'''Upper-body''' *Push ups *Bench dips *Back extensions *Medicine ball chest pass *Bench lift *Inclined press up '''Core & trunk''' *Sit ups (lower abdominal) *Stomach crunch (upper abdominal) *Back extension chest raise '''Lower-body''' *Squat jumps *Compass jumps *Astride jumps *Step ups *Shuttle runs *Hopping shuttles *Bench squats '''Total-body''' *[[Burpee (exercise)|Burpees]] *Treadmills *Squat thrusts *Skipping *Jogging
==Effects of circuit training== Studies at Baylor University and The Cooper Institute show that circuit training is the most time efficient way to enhance cardiovascular fitness and muscle endurance. Studies show that circuit training helps women to achieve their goals and maintain them longer than other forms of exercise or diet.<ref name="Curves">Heavin, Gary and Colman, Carol, C. Reprint edition (December 7, 2004). ''Curves: Permanent Results Without Permanent Dieting'', {{ISBN|0-399-52956-X}}</ref>
Morgan and Anderson claim: {{quote| Perhaps a most profound finding of this study, from a health perspective, is that this investigation clearly shows that performance of this circuit of exercises,this level of intensity elicited oxygen consumption values (39% to 51.5% of VO2max) that meet established guidelines of the [[American College of Sports Medicine]] (ACSM) for the recommended intensity (40% to 85% of [[VO2max]]R) of exercise for developing and maintaining cardio-respiratory fitness.<ref>{{cite web|last=Klika|first=Brett|title=High-Intensity Circuit Training Using Body Weight: Maximum Results With Minimal Investment|url=http://journals.lww.com/acsm-healthfitness/Fulltext/2013/05000/HIGH_INTENSITY_CIRCUIT_TRAINING_USING_BODY_WEIGHT_.5.aspx#P98 |publisher=ACSM's Health & Fitness Journal|accessdate=20 September 2013|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Thus, this circuit not only provides a suitable muscular fitness stimulus but also helps to meet ACSM cardiovascular guidelines and the newly published Dietary Guidelines for Americans 2005 for physical activity.<ref name="UNM" /> }}
One advantage is that reduced station times will encourage the participants to lift heavier weights, which means they can achieve overload with smaller number of repetitions: typically in the range of 25 to 50 depending on their training goals.<ref name="ACSM">http://westvalley.edu/academics/pe_department/physical_education/programs/weighttraining/acsm-resistancetraining.pdf</ref>
==See also== * [[Bodyweight exercise]] * [[Threshold training]] * [[Calisthenics]] * [[General fitness training]] * [[High-intensity interval training]] * [[Interval training]] * [[Isometric exercise]] * [[Long slow distance]] *[[Power training]] * [[Plyometric]] * [[Endurance training|Resistance training]] * [[Stretching]] * [[Supercompensation]] * [[Weight training]] * [[vVO2max|vVO<sub>2</sub>max]]
== References == {{reflist}} {{refbegin}} * Kravitz, L. (1996). "The fitness professional's complete guide to circuits and intervals". ''IDEA Today'', 14(1), 32–43. * {{Cite journal | title = American College of Sports Medicine Position Stand. The recommended quantity and quality of exercise for developing and maintaining cardiorespiratory and muscular fitness, and flexibility in healthy adults | journal = Medicine & Science in Sports & Exercise | volume = 30 | issue = 6 | pages = 975–991 | year = 1998 | pmid = 9624661 | doi=10.1097/00005768-199806000-00032 }} {{refend}}
{{Physical exercise}}
